defs.etymology: From Middle French de, from Old French de, from Latin dē.

text: of (used to express property or association)
used attributively, often translated into English as a compound word
from (used to indicate the start of a time or range)
used after certain verbs before an infinitive, often translated into English as a gerund or an infinitive
examples: Dans une bourgade de la Manche, dont je ne veux pas me rappeler le nom, vivait, il n’y a pas longtemps, un hidalgo ....In a village of La Mancha, whose name I do not want to remember, lived, not long ago, an hidalgo ....
In a village of La Mancha, whose name I do not want to remember, lived, not long ago, an hidalgo ....
Paris est la capitale de la France. ― Paris is the capital of France.
Œuvres de Fermat ― Fermat’s Works
Elle est la femme de mon ami. ― She is my friend’s wife.
le voisin de Gabriel ― Gabriel's neighbor
Elle vient de France. ― She comes from France.
Êtes-vous de Suisse ? ― Are you from Switzerland?
Ce fromage vient d’Espagne. ― This cheese is from Spain.
C’est de l’ouest de la France. ― It’s from the west of France.
Le train va de Paris à Bordeaux. ― The train goes from Paris to Bordeaux.
5 kilos de pommes. ― 5 kilograms of apples.
Un verre de vin ― A glass of wine
Une portion de frites ― A portion of fries
Un jus de pomme ― Apple juice
Un verre de vin ― A glass of wine
Une boîte de nuit ― A nightclub
Un chien de garde ― A guarddog
Une voiture de sport ― A sportscar
Un stade de football ― A football stadium
De 9:00 à 11:00 je ne serai pas libre. ― From 9 to 11 I won’t be free.
Je travaille de huit heures à midi. ― I work from 8 o'clock to noon.
un groupe de cinq à huit personnes ― a group of [from] five to eight people
J’ai arrêté de fumer. ― I stopped smoking.
Il continue de m’embêter. ― He keeps annoying me.
Elle m’a dit de venir. ― She told me to come.
Nous vous exhortons de venir. ― We urge you to come.
Boire trois tasses par jour réduirait de 20 % les risques de contracter une maladie. ― Drinking three cups a day would reduce the risks of catching an illness by 20%.

text: Used in the plural with prepositioned adjectives.
Used in negated sentences with the grammatical object.
examples: Ce sont de bons enfants. ― They are good children.
Il y a d’autres exemples. ― There are other examples.
Elle n’a pas de mère. ― She doesn’t have a mother.
Il ne mange pas de viande. ― He doesn’t eat meat.
Il n’y a pas de problèmes. ― There are no problems.

defs.etymology:
Inherited from Old French jo, from Vulgar Latin *eo, from Latin ego, from Proto-Indo-European *éǵh₂. Near cognates include Spanish yo and Italian io. Further cognates include Ancient Greek ἐγώ (egṓ), Russian я (ja), English I, German ich, etc.
See cognates in regional languages in France: Angevin, Bourbonnais-Berrichon, Gallo, Lorrain, Norman, Orléanais, Tourangeau, and Franco-Provençal je; Bourguignon je or i; Champenois ju; Franc-Comtois i; Picard ej; Poitevin-Saintongeais jhe; Occitan ieu (Gascon jo); Catalan jo; Corsican eo.

text: je (first person singular, plural nous, object me, emphatic moi)

words: “je”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

defs.etymology: From Old French, from Old English ēast.
From Latin est, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *h₁ésti.

text: third-person singular present indicative of être

defs.etymology:
From Old French pas, from Latin passus.
Its use as an auxiliary negative adverb comes from an accusative use (Latin nec… passum) in negative constructions – literally “not… a step”, i.e. “not at all” – originally used with certain verbs of motion. In older French other nouns could also be used in this way, such as ne… goutte (“not… a drop”) and ne… mie (“not… a crumb”), but in the modern language pas has become grammaticalised.

text: thread, pitch (of a screw or nut)
examples: Des pas qu'on gravait dans la neige sont partis avec le printemps.Steps we etched in the snow are gone with the [arrival of] spring.
Steps we etched in the snow are gone with the [arrival of] spring.
Pas de Calais ― Strait of Dover

text: The most common adverb of negation in French, typically translating into English as not, don't, doesn't, etc.
examples: Je ne sais pas.I don't know
I don't know
Ma grande sœur n'habite pas avec nous.My big sister doesn't live with us.
My big sister doesn't live with us.
J’veux pas travailler.I don't wanna work.
I don't wanna work.

defs.etymology: From Middle French le, from Old French le, from Latin illum, by dropping il- and -m. Latin illum is the accusative singular of ille.

text: le m (feminine la, neuter lea, masculine and feminine plural les)
Used before abstract nouns; not translated in English.
(before parts of the body) the; my, your, etc.
examples: Le lait du matin. ― The milk of the morning.
Il s’est cassé la jambe. ― He has broken his leg.
Cinquante kilomètres à l’heure. ― fifty kilometres an hour

text: le m (feminine la, masculine and feminine plural les)
used to refer to something previously mentioned or implied; not translated in English

words: ^  Dauzat, Albert; Jean Dubois, Henri Mitterand (1964),  “le, la, les”, in Nouveau dictionnaire étymologique (in French), Paris: Librairie Larousse

examples: Je suis petit et lui, il l’est aussi. ― I am small and he is too

ipa.kind: before a word starting with a vowel

defs.etymology: From Latin quid, usurping some of the roles of Latin quod.

text: that (introduces a subordinate noun clause and connects it to its parent clause)
Substitutes for another, previously stated conjunction.
Links two noun phrases in apposition forming a clause without a (finite) verb, such that the complement acts as predicate.
examples: Si on s'en allait tout là-haut, si on prenait de la hauteur, tu verrais que le monde est beau, beau.
Je vois que tu parles bien français.I see that you speak French well.
I see that you speak French well.
Si le temps est beau et que tout le monde est d'accord, nous mangerons en plein air.If the weather is nice and if everyone likes the idea, we'll eat outside.
If the weather is nice and if everyone likes the idea, we'll eat outside.
Il était à peine parti qu’elle a téléphoné à la police.No sooner had he left when she called the police.
No sooner had he left when she called the police.

—Quelle grande bête, avec tout son esprit, que votre marquise, pour vous avoir dit pareille chose! — fit la duchesse  […].‘What a beast your marquise is, for all her spirit, for having told you such a thing!’ said the duchess.
‘What a beast your marquise is, for all her spirit, for having told you such a thing!’ said the duchess.
Quelle belle fleur que la rose! dit-elle soudain, alors qu'aucune rose n'était en vue […].‘What a beautiful flower the rose is!’ she said suddenly, though no rose was in sight.
‘What a beautiful flower the rose is!’ she said suddenly, though no rose was in sight.

defs.etymology: From Latin quam.

examples: Il est plus grand que son père.He is taller than his father.
He is taller than his father.
Je ne mange que des fruits.I eat nothing but fruit.
I eat nothing but fruit.

Nous souhaitons la vérité et ne trouvons en nous qu’incertitude. Nous recherchons le bonheur et ne trouvons que misère et mort.We hope for truth and find in ourselves nothing but uncertainty. We search again for happiness and find only misery and death.

Nous souhaitons la vérité et ne trouvons en nous qu’incertitude. Nous recherchons le bonheur et ne trouvons que misère et mort.We hope for truth and find in ourselves nothing but uncertainty. We search again for happiness and find only misery and death.
We hope for truth and find in ourselves nothing but uncertainty. We search again for happiness and find only misery and death.
Elle est aussi intelligente que toi.She is as smart as you.
She is as smart as you.
Que c'est beau!How beautiful it is!
How beautiful it is!

defs.etymology: From Latin quid, from Proto-Indo-European *kʷid, compare *kʷis. Doublet of quoi 'what', the tonic/emphasized counterpart, hence diphthongized.

text: (slightly formal, accusative) The inanimate direct-object interrogative pronoun.
(slightly formal, nominative) The inanimate subject or predicative interrogative pronoun.
examples: Qu’a-t-on fait de la vérité ?
Que pensez-vous de cette peinture ?What do you think of that painting?
What do you think of that painting?
Qu'auriez-vous fait d'autre ?
Qu'est-il arrivé ? ― What happened?
Que me vaut cette visite ? ― To what do I owe this visit?
Que sommes-nous ? ― What are we?

defs.etymology: From Latin quem, accusative of qui.

text: (accusative, relative) The direct object relative pronoun.
examples: C'est un homme que je connais très bien.He's a man whom I know very well.
He's a man whom I know very well.
Je viens de lire la lettre que vous m'avez envoyée.I've just read the letter that you sent me.
I've just read the letter that you sent me.

defs.etymology: From Middle French la, from Old French la, from Latin illam, which is the accusative singular feminine of ille.

From Middle French vous, from Old French vos, vous, from Latin vōs, from Proto-Italic *wōs.
See cognates in regional languages in France: Angevin, Bourbonnais-Berrichon, Bourguignon, Champenois, Lorrain, Orléanais, and Poitevin-Saintongeais vous; Franc-Comtois vôs; Gallo vouz; Norman, Tourangeau, and Franco-Provençal vos; Picard os; Occitan vosautres (Provençal vousautes); Catalan vosaltres; Corsican voi.

text: the plural personal pronoun in the second person:
(formal, polite) plural or singular personal pronoun in the second person

words: “vous”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

examples: Vous allez ― You go.
Je vous adore. ― I love you.
Je vous donnerai mon adresse. ― I will give you my address / I will give my address to you.
Monsieur, je ne peux pas vous le dire ― Sir, I cannot tell you.

defs.etymology: From Old French tu, from Latin tū, from Proto-Italic *tū, from Proto-Indo-European *túh₂.

text: tu (second person informal singular, possessive determiner ton)

words: vous (plural form and polite singular form)

defs.etymology: From t-il.
From Old French un, from Latin ūnum, accusative singular of ūnus (“one”), from Old Latin oinos, from Proto-Italic *oinos, from Proto-Indo-European *óynos.

text: un m (feminine une, plural des, negative de)
When used as a numeral or noun, it is treated as aspirated (no liaison with that which precedes). Compare onze.
When used as an article or pronoun, liaison does apply normally.
A with grave accent, a letter used in French mostly to distinguish some homographs and in transliteration.

defs.etymology: From Old French a, a merge of Latin ad and ab, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂éd and *h₂epó.

text: at, in, on (said of a particular place)
Used to make compound nouns to state what something is used for
(before an infinitive) to (used to express something not completed)
Used to describe a part of something, often translated into English as a compound adjective
or, to (used to express an approximate number)
Used to indicate the recipient of certain phrasal verb.
examples: Je vais à Paris. ― I am going to Paris.
aller au bout ― go to the end / go all the way
Le spectacle sera de 18h à 21h. ― The show will be from 6 pm to 9 pm.
Tournez à gauche ! ― Turn [to the] left!
Ne tournez pas encore à droite ! ― Don't turn [to the] right yet!
Le vent vire au nord. ― The wind turns north.
L'école est à gauche. ― The school is on the left.
Je pars à cinq heures précises. ― I am leaving at exactly five o'clock.
à dix heures et quart ― at quarter past ten
à la maison ― at home
à l'hôtel ― at the hotel
au comptoir du bar ― at the bar
au bois ― in the woods
J'habite à un demi-kilomètre d'ici. ― I live half a kilometer from here.
La maison qui a été détruite hier soir ne se trouvait qu'à  trois kilomètres de chez nous.The house that was destroyed last night was only three kilometers from our place.
The house that was destroyed last night was only three kilometers from our place.
Nous prenons de l'eau au puits. ― We get water from the well.
Je l'ai eu à la bibliothèque. ― I got it from the library.
Voilà la femme à laquelle j'ai acheté mon chien ― There's the woman I bought my dog from.
Synonym:  de
C'est un ami à moi. ― This is a friend of mine.
Cette voiture est à John. ― This is John's car.
le chien à Marie ― Mary's dog [nonstandard: one normally would use de here]
à plus tard ― see you later
à bientôt ― see you soon
Salut, donc. À demain. ― Bye, then. 'Til tomorrow / see you tomorrow.
moulin à poivre ― pepper mill
sac à dos ― backpack
boite à musique ― music box
Il n'y a jamais grand-chose à faire par ici. ― There's never much to do around here.
Là où tu ne vois pas grand-chose, je ne trouve qu'une grande abondance de choses qui restent à faire. ― Where you see nothing great, I only see a great abundance of things that need doing.
Il reste deux tâches à finir. ― There are two things left to finish.
Il y a de la bière à boire. ― There's some beer to drink.
l'équipe à battre ― the team to beat
un animal à quatre pattes ― a four-legged animal
une femme au visage pâle ― a pale-faced woman
un homme à longue barbe ― a long-bearded man — a man with a long beard
une chemise à manches courtes ― a short-sleeved shirt
une maison aux murs de brique ― a brick-walled house / a house with brick walls
peu à peu ― bit by bit
petit à petit ― little by little
minute à minute ― minute by minute
jour à jour ― day by day
un à un ― one  by one
six à sept personnes ― six or seven people
de vingt à trente ans ― from twenty to thirty years
tous les cinq à six ans ― every five or six years
mettre le feu à ― to set fire to
clouer le bec à ― to shut  up
donner la chasse à ― to give chase to

Bien que la faim et le dénûment nous tourmentassent quelquefois, et même à peu près toujours, rien ne nous causait autant de tourment que d'être témoins des cruautés inouïes que mon maître exerçait sur les chrétiens. Chaque jour il en faisait pendre quelqu'un; on empalait celui-là, on coupait les oreilles à celui-ci  […] .Even though hunger and destitution tormented us sometimes, and even almost always, nothing caused us as much torment as being witnesses to the unheard-of cruelties that my master exercised on the Christians. Every day, he made someone hang; they impaled that one, they cut the ears off of this one […] .

Even though hunger and destitution tormented us sometimes, and even almost always, nothing caused us as much torment as being witnesses to the unheard-of cruelties that my master exercised on the Christians. Every day, he made someone hang; they impaled that one, they cut the ears off of this one […] .

On peut remarquer, à ce propos, que ce n'est pas non plus dans des livre à prétention plus ou moins scientifique que Kraus avait l'habitude de chercher les instruments dont il avait besoin pour la déscription et l'expliquation.It may also be noticed, on this matter, that it is also not on books with more or less scientific pretentions that Kraus used to search for the instruments which he needed for description and explanation.

On peut remarquer, à ce propos, que ce n'est pas non plus dans des livre à prétention plus ou moins scientifique que Kraus avait l'habitude de chercher les instruments dont il avait besoin pour la déscription et l'expliquation.It may also be noticed, on this matter, that it is also not on books with more or less scientific pretentions that Kraus used to search for the instruments which he needed for description and explanation.

It may also be noticed, on this matter, that it is also not on books with more or less scientific pretentions that Kraus used to search for the instruments which he needed for description and explanation.

defs.etymology: From Middle French et, from Old French et, from Latin et.
From Middle French il, from Old French il, from Vulgar Latin *illī, which is derived from Classical Latin ille.

text: il (third-person singular, plural ils, accusative le, dative lui, emphatic lui)
he (third-person singular masculine subject pronoun for human subject)
it (third-person singular subject pronoun for grammatically masculine objects)

words: ^  Dauzat, Albert; Jean Dubois, Henri Mitterand (1964),  chapter IL, in Nouveau dictionnaire étymologique (in French), Paris: Librairie Larousse

examples: Il est parti.He left.
He left.
Je cherche mon livre. Où est-il ?I'm looking for my book. Where is it?
I'm looking for my book. Where is it?
Il pleut.It’s raining.
It’s raining.

text: The first letter of the French alphabet, written in the Latin script.
a, the name of the Latin-script letter A

defs.etymology: Quebec eye-dialect spelling of elle.

examples: C'te fille-là, a'a l'air cute. This girl, she looks cute.
This girl, she looks cute.

text: third-person singular present indicative of avoir
examples: Elle a un chat. She has a cat.
She has a cat.

text: (before a vowel) Apocopic form of le, la: the
(Quebec, colloquial, after a vowel) Apocopic form of le: the
examples: À la manifestation, / on rêvait d'révolution / se gelant l'cul avec une poignée de comparses / sous la pluie froide du mois d'mars

text: (before a vowel) Apocopic form of le, la: him, her, it
(Quebec, colloquial, after a vowel) Apocopic form of le: him, it

words: “l'”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

examples: Icitte y'a papa qui se r'met / fe sa p'tite opération / t'aurais du l'voir, y fakait / fallait l'traiter aux p'tits oignons

defs.etymology: From Latin nōn.
From Middle French les, from Old French les, from Latin illōs m and illās f which are the accusative plurals of ille.

text: les m pl or f pl

words: ^  Dauzat, Albert; Jean Dubois, Henri Mitterand (1964),  “le, la, les”, in Nouveau dictionnaire étymologique (in French), Paris: Librairie Larousse
“j'”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

examples: J’ai sommeil. ― I’m sleepy.
J’habite à Paris. ― I live in Paris.
J’veux pas savoir. ― I don't wanna know.
J’comprends. ― I understand.

defs.etymology: From Middle French en, from Old French en, from Latin in, from Proto-Italic *en, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁én (“in”).

text: in (used to indicate space, also see usage notes)
to (indicates direction towards certain very large locations, see usage notes)
of, made of (used to describe composition)
in (during the following time (used for months and years))
(followed by a gerund) by, in (describing a way of getting something)
examples: J'habite en Angleterre. ― I live in England.
Il est allé en France. ― He went to France.
aller en bus ― go by bus
partir en voiture ― leave by car
Il me traite en ami. ― He treats me as a friend.
habillé en père Noël ― dressed as Father Christmas
fort en histoire ― good at history
une chaise en hêtre ― a chair made of beech/a beech chair
une fourchette en métal ― a fork made of metal/a metal fork
en janvier ― in January
en septembre 2001 ― in September 2001
C'est en trichant qu'il est devenu champion. ― It was by cheating that he became champion.
une photo en noir et blanc ― a photo in black and white
en détresse ― in distress
en équipe ― on a team

defs.etymology: From Latin inde (“thence”). Compare Catalan en, Italian ne.

text: Used as the object of a verb to indicate an indefinite quantity; of it, of them. Replaces the partitive article (du, de la, etc.)
Adverbial preposition indicating movement away from a place already mentioned; from there, from it. Replaces the phrase de là or d’ici.
examples: Essaies-en ! Try some !
Try some !
Tu as combien de livres ? J'en ai trois. How many books do you have? I have three .
How many books do you have? I have three .
Y a-t-il beaucoup de pièces ? Oui. Il y en a beaucoup. Are there many rooms? Yes, there are many .
Are there many rooms? Yes, there are many .
Martin a trois sandwichs, mais j'en ai seulement deux. Martin has three sandwiches, but I have only two .
Martin has three sandwiches, but I have only two .
Il y en a combien ? How many of them are there?
How many of them are there?
Je bois de l'alcool parce que j'en ai besoin I drink alcohol because I need  it.
I drink alcohol because I need  it.

J'en donnerai ici la méthode, que je poursuivrai seulement en deux ou trois exemples, qui seront si aisés à continuer qu'il ne sera pas nécessaire d'en donner davantage.I shall give  here the method that I shall pursue only in two or three examples, which will be so easy to continue that it will not be necessary to give more of them.
I shall give  here the method that I shall pursue only in two or three examples, which will be so easy to continue that it will not be necessary to give more of them.
Est-ce qu'elle vient de Barcelone ? Oui, elle en vient. Does she come from Barcelona? Yes, she comes .
Does she come from Barcelona? Yes, she comes .

defs.etymology: From Old French hom, om (nominative form), from Latin homō (“human being”) (compare homme from the Old French oblique form home, from the Latin accusative form hominem). Its pronominal use is of Germanic origin. Compare Old English man (“one, they, people”), reduced form of Old English mann (“person”); Catalan hom; German man (“one, they, people”); Dutch men (“one, they, people”).

text: (indefinite) one, people, you, someone (an unspecified individual)
examples: Synonyms: quelqu'un , l'on
Quand on cherche l'amour...When one searches for love...
When one searches for love...
On ne peut pas pêcher ici ― You can’t fish here
Synonym: nous
On oublie nos certitudesWe forget our certainties
We forget our certainties
On s’est amusés. ― We had fun.

defs.etymology: Contraction of cela..

examples: J'aimerais ça. ― I'd like that.
Je veux ça. ― I want this.
Ça va. ― It's okay.

defs.etymology: From Old French, from Latin ūna, feminine of ūnus.

examples: Dans une bourgade de la Manche, dont je ne veux pas me rappeler le nom, vivait, il n’y a pas longtemps, un hidalgo ....In a village of La Mancha, whose name I do not want to remember, lived, not long ago, an hidalgo ....
In a village of La Mancha, whose name I do not want to remember, lived, not long ago, an hidalgo ....

defs.etymology: Contraction of the preposition de (“of, from”).

text: (before a vowel or a mute h) Apocopic form of de: of
(informal, after a vowel sound) Apocopic form of de: of
examples: un verre d'eaua glass of water
a glass of water
Hé Rémi / fais pas d'conneries / J't'aime ben la face / pis tu m'dois encore cinquante piassesHey Rémi / stop with the nonsense / I really like your face / and you still owe me fifty dollars
Hey Rémi / stop with the nonsense / I really like your face / and you still owe me fifty dollars

defs.etymology: From Middle French [Term?], from Old French cel, from earlier cil, from Vulgar Latin eccille.
From Old French ço, from Vulgar Latin *ecce hoc.

text: (subject of être, with predicative adjectives or relative clauses, singular only) it, this, that (see § Usage notes, below)
(subject of être, with predicate nouns) he, she, it, this, that
(archaic, subject of verbs other than être) it, this, that
examples: C'est beau ! ― It is beautiful!
ce dont je parlais ― that which I was speaking of
C'eût été avec plaisir, mais... ― It would have been with pleasure, but...
C'eût été dommage... ― It would have been a pity...
C'est un/e célébrité. ― He/she/it is a celebrity.
Ce sont des célébrités. ― These are celebrities.
Ce sont des gens bien. ― These are good people.
C'est un roc ! ... c'est un pic ! ... c'est un cap ! Que dis-je, c'est un cap ? ... C'est une péninsule !
[...] ce paraissent être encore là des points à noter [...]
ce semble ― it seems
ce peuvent être... ― these may be...

defs.etymology: From que.

text: (before vowel sound) Apocopic form of que (that, which)
(informal, before consonants) Apocopic form of que (that, which)
examples: Anyway chuis content que tu r'viennes / t'arrives en même temps qu'l'automne / Tsé qu'ça m'a fait ben d'la peine / de t'voir partir ma mignonne

text: (before vowel sound) Apocopic form of que (what, that, whom; only)

defs.etymology: From Middle French pour, from Old French por, pur, from Vulgar Latin *por, from Latin prō.

text: for (meant for, intended for) (followed by a noun or pronoun)
to (to bring about an intended result) (followed by a verb in the infinitive)
examples: J'ai un cadeau pour toi.I've got a gift for you.
I've got a gift for you.
Pourquoi voter pour lui ?Why did you vote vote for him?
Why did you vote vote for him?
Il faut le punir pour ses crimes.He must be punished for his crimes.
He must be punished for his crimes.
Sébastien est parti pour Londres.Sébastien left for London.
Sébastien left for London.
Comment faire pour tuer mes démons ?
Je veux chanter pour te faire revenir.I want to sing to make you come back.
I want to sing to make you come back.
Pour moi, ce film est trop irréaliste.For me, this film is too unrealistic.
For me, this film is too unrealistic.

text: first-person singular present indicative of avoir
examples: J'ai un chien.I have a dog.
I have a dog.

defs.etymology: The use as an article is a special case of the contraction.

text: des m pl or f pl
plural of un (“some; the plural indefinite article”)
plural of une (“some; the plural indefinite article”)
plural of du (“some; the plural partitive article”)
plural of de la (“some; the plural partitive article”)
plural of de l' (“some; the plural partitive article”)

defs.etymology: From Middle French qui, from Old French qui, from Latin quī..

text: (relative) who, whom (after a preposition), which, that
examples: Tu as vu qui ?Who have you seen?
Who have you seen?
La personne qui parle connait bien son sujet.The person who speaks knows his/her subject well.
The person who speaks knows his/her subject well.
Cette voiture bleue qui passe me plait beaucoup.This blue car which is passing I like a lot.
This blue car which is passing I like a lot.
J’aime les chiens qui sont calmes.I like dogs that are quiet.
I like dogs that are quiet.
Un homme à qui j’ai parlé.A man to whom I spoke/have spoken.
A man to whom I spoke/have spoken.
Si lugubre que fût l’appartement, c’était un paradis pour qui revenait du lycée.Gloomy as the apartment was, it was still a paradise for those who came back from school.
Gloomy as the apartment was, it was still a paradise for those who came back from school.
Rira bien qui rira le dernier.Who laughs last laughs well.
Who laughs last laughs well.
Qui elle en a, ça va faire.If she has any, that will do.
If she has any, that will do.

defs.etymology: From Old French mes, mais, from Latin magis.

text: an expression of surprise, disbelief, or frustration roughly equivalent to the English well, or sometimes yeah
examples: Mais qu'est-ce que tu fais ? ― What the heck are you doing?

defs.etymology: From Old French denz, from Vulgar Latin deintus, from Latin de intus, meaning "from inside" or "from within".

text: (literally, figuratively) in, inside (enclosed in a physical space, a group, a state)
(Should we delete(+) this sense?) in, into (from outside, to inside)
in, within (a longer period of time)
examples: vieillir dans la misère ― to grow old in poverty
être dans l'infanterie ― to be in the infantry
avoir quelque chose dans la bouche ― to have something in the mouth
dans les circonstances d'une pandémie ― under the circumstances of a pandemic
Il habite dans le quartier le plus riche de Paris. ― He lives in the richest district of Paris.
Il nage comme un poisson dans l'eau. ― He swims like a fish in the water.

Dans une bourgade de la Manche, dont je ne veux pas me rappeler le nom, vivait, il n'y a pas longtemps, un hidalgo […] In a village of La Mancha, whose name I do not want to remember, lived, not long ago, an hidalgo […]
In a village of La Mancha, whose name I do not want to remember, lived, not long ago, an hidalgo […]
mettre l'argent dans la poche ― to put money into one's pocket
Bienvenue dans le meilleur bar de tout Paris.Welcome to the best bar in all of Paris.
Welcome to the best bar in all of Paris.
Je serai prêt dans une heure. ― I'll be ready in one hour.
Il arrivera dans trois jours. ― He will arrive in three days.
dans un temps donné ― during a given time
dans ma jeunesse ― in my youth
boire dans une tasse ― to drink from a cup
Il prend le beurre dans le réfrigérateur. ― He takes the butter out of the fridge.
le marxisme dans Sartre ― Marxism in the works of Sartre
dans les trentes kilos ― about thirty kilos
dans les dix euros ― about ten euros

defs.etymology: See dan.

From Middle French nous, from Old French nous, nos, from Latin nōs, from Proto-Italic *nōs.
In several dialects of French, je may be used instead of nous (j'allons instead of nous allons, je voyons instead of nous voyons etc.), this use was perceived as peasant-like and thus often mocked since the 15th century (for example by Molière). However this use survived and spread in various regions of the so-called domaine d'oïl (linguistic area starting above Auvergne where the oïl varieties of Romance developed from the 4th or 5th century). The regions of France where this use of je (from Latin ego "I") instead of nous, nos (from Latin nos, "we") was recorded are Normandy, Romance-speaking Brittany, Poitou and Anjou, Champagne, Ardennes, Bourgogne and Franche-Comté, Dauphiné, Berry, Touraine, Orléanais, Bourbonnais, Maine.
See cognates in regional languages in France: Angevin je and nous, Bourbonnais-Berrichon je and nous, Bourguignon i and nous, Champenois ju and nous, Franc-Comtois i and nôs, Gallo je and nouz, Lorrain nos, Norman je and nos, Orléanais je and nous, Picard nos, Poitevin-Saintongeais i/jhe and nous, Tourangeau je and nos, Franco-Provençal nos, Occitan nosautres (Provençal nousautes), Catalan nosaltres, Corsican noi.

text: nous m pl or f pl
the plural personal pronoun in the first person:

defs.etymology: From Ancient Greek νοῦς (noûs) or νόος (nóos, “mind”).
From Old French ele, from Latin illa, feminine of ille.

text: it (feminine gender third-person singular subject pronoun)
disjunctive form of elle; her; à elle = hers

words: The name of the Latin-script letter L.

examples: Je crois qu'elle est partie.I think she left.
I think she left.
Voilà ma voiture. Elle a cinq ans.That's my car. It is five years old.
That's my car. It is five years old.
C’est à elle.It's hers.
It's hers.

text: The name of the Latin-script letter L.

defs.etymology: From Middle French me, from Old French me, from Latin mē (accusative of ego), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁me- (“me”). Northern dialects have preserved a form mi for the indirect object (also found in Old French in the Oaths of Strasbourg), from Latin mihi, dative singular of ego, through a Vulgar Latin *mi, whereas in standard French, it has merged into me.

words: “me”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

examples: Est-ce que tu me vois ? ― Do you see me?
Émilien me donne un peu d'argent. ― Émilien gave some money to me.

defs.etymology: From Middle French bien, from Old French bien, from Latin bene (“well”).

text: (followed by de, des, or du) a lot (of)
examples: Ça va bien ? ― How's it going?
Il joue vraiment bien au football.He plays soccer really well.
He plays soccer really well.
Synonym: alors
Bien, on peut partir maintenant ?So, can we leave now?
So, can we leave now?
Macy Gray a traversé bien des épreuves.Macy Gray got through a lot of ordeals.
Macy Gray got through a lot of ordeals.
Est-ce que les parfums s'évaporent, ou restent-ils dans notre tête comme ces étoiles qui brillent encore, mais qui sont bien loin de la fête ?
C'est bien aimable à vous. ― it's very considerate of you.
C'est bien beau, mais... ― It's all very well, but...
Je te trouve bien silencieux aujourd'hui. ― You seem very quiet today.
Il est bien moche, ce type. Ce type est vraiment moche. ― That guy is really ugly.
Jérémie est bien plus fort que moi.Jérémie is much stronger than me.
Jérémie is much stronger than me.
bien meilleur que  […] much better than  […]
much better than  […]

defs.etymology: From Old French se, from Latin si (“if”).

examples: Je me demande si elle sera seule.I wonder if she'll be alone.
I wonder if she'll be alone.
Je veux savoir si tu viendras ou non.I want to know if you're coming or not.
I want to know if you're coming or not.
Si j'avais ses pouvoirs, je créerais un monde où le mal n'existe pas.If I had his power, I'd create a world where evil didn't exist.
If I had his power, I'd create a world where evil didn't exist.
Si tu n'avais pas appelé, je serais morte.If you hadn't called, I'd be dead.
If you hadn't called, I'd be dead.

defs.etymology: From Old French si, from Latin sic (“so, thus”). Doublet of sic.

text: yes (used to contradict a negative statement) (often followed by I do, he is, etc. in English to indicate contradiction rather than affirmation)
examples: Tu ne m’aimes pas, n’est-ce pas ? — Si !You don’t like me, do you? — Yes, I do!
You don’t like me, do you? — Yes, I do!
Moi, je n'ai rien fait ! — Si !I didn't do anything! — Yes, you did!
I didn't do anything! — Yes, you did!
Synonym:  si fait

text: (si + adjective/adverb + que ... ) however (to whatever extent or degree)
examples: J’étais si fatigué ces jours-ci que je n’avais pas le courage de vous écrire.I was so tired those days that I didn't have the energy to write to you.
I was so tired those days that I didn't have the energy to write to you.
Cela n'aurait pas été une si bonne idée.That wouldn't have been such a good idea.
That wouldn't have been such a good idea.
Synonyms: aussi, tout, quelque

Mais un législateur qui aurait un tant soit peu de valeur, si infime soit elle, quand bien même il n'en irait pas comme l'argument vient de le démontrer, n'aurait-il pas commis en cette occasion, plus qu'en n'importe quelle autre circonstance où il aurait eu l'audace de mentir aux jeunes gens dans l'intérêt du bien, son plus utile mensonge, celui capable de faire que tous, non pas de force mais de leur plein gré, se conduisent de façon entièrement juste ?
Si bavard qu'il soit, il ne dit rien de stupide.However talkative he may be, he doesn't say anything stupid.
However talkative he may be, he doesn't say anything stupid.

defs.etymology: From Old French del. The expected modern form would be *deau, but it underwent stronger contraction.
From i grec (“Greek i”), referring to the letter upsilon (Υ), originally borrowed from the Greek alphabet, as opposed to "Latin i" (I).

text: a letter in the French alphabet, after x and before z

defs.etymology: 10th century; from Old French i, from Latin hīc (“here”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰi-ḱe (“this, here”)), with meaning influenced by Old French iv (“there, thither”), itself from Latin ibī. Derivation from the latter poses difficulty from a phonetic standpoint. Compare Catalan hi.

text: Used as a pronoun to replace an adverbial phrase starting with à.
examples: Il est dans la maison. Il y est.He is in the house. He is there.
He is in the house. He is there.
Nous allons au Mexique. Nous y allons.We are going to Mexico. We are going there.
We are going to Mexico. We are going there.
Je pense à mon pays. J'y pense.I think about my country. I think about it.
I think about my country. I think about it.
personnes y nommées ― Persons named there
procédures y afférentes ― Related procedures
documents y relatifs ― Related documents
eaux y affluentes ― Tributary waters

defs.etymology: Eye dialect spelling or contraction of il and ils.

text: (Quebec, France, colloquial) he: alternative form of il
(Quebec, France, colloquial) they: alternative form of ils
(Quebec, colloquial) they: alternative form of elles

defs.etymology: From Middle French suis, from Old French sui, from Latin sum. The expected Old French reflex of sum would be *son. The form sui goes back to a Vulgar Latin *suī, which was probably influenced by the perfect tense fuī (“I was”, modern French fus). Compare the reverse development in Galician fun (“I was”), from Vulgar Latin *fum, influenced by the present form. Final -s was added in later Old French to the first-person singular forms by analogy with the second person; it was standardised in Modern French in most cases except after unstressed -e and in the ending -ai of the future and past historic.

text: first-person singular present indicative of être

defs.etymology: Inflected forms of suivre.

text: first/second-person singular present indicative of suivre

defs.etymology: From Old French non, from Latin nōn.

examples: Êtes-vous toujours en prière ?  Êtes-vous des astres blessés ?  Car ce sont des pleurs de lumière,  Non des rayons, que vous versez.Are you still in prayer?  Are you hurt stars?  Because it is cries of light,  Not rays, that you pour.
Are you still in prayer?  Are you hurt stars?  Because it is cries of light,  Not rays, that you pour.

words: “t'”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

examples: Je t’ai vu.I saw you.
I saw you.
T’as vu mon frère ?Have you seen my brother?
Have you seen my brother?

defs.etymology: From Middle French avec, avecques (“with”), from Old French avoc, avoec, avuec (“with”), from an assumed Vulgar Latin *aboc, *abhoc, *apud hŏque, from Latin apud (“with, near, close to”) + hoc (“this”) + -que. First used as a replacement for Latin cum (“with”) in Merovingian and Carolingian documents from France. Gradually supplanted Old French od (“with”), itself from apud (od survives however in some dialects in Western France under the form d'ot).Cognate with Picard avuc, Narom aveuc, Walloon avou and, more distantly, with Franco-Provençal avoi (from *ab hoc and not *abhocque).

examples: Je suis revenu avec lui.I have returned with him.
I have returned with him.
Voudriez-vous y aller avec moi ?Would you like to come with me?
Would you like to come with me?
Ils m'ont dit qu'ils étaient avec toi.They told me that they were with you.
They told me that they were with you.
Je l'ai fait avec plaisir.I did it with pleasure.
I did it with pleasure.
Il en est vraiment content. —Bien, moi avec.He's really happy about it. —Well, me too.
He's really happy about it. —Well, me too.

defs.etymology: From Middle French tout, from Old French tot, from Vulgar Latin tōttus, alteration (likely via expressive gemination) of Latin tōtus. Compare Catalan tot, Italian tutto, Portuguese todo, Romanian tot, Spanish todo.

text: tout (feminine toute, masculine plural tous, feminine plural toutes)

defs.etymology: From Old French plus, from Latin plus, from Old Latin *plous, from Proto-Indo-European *pleh₁-, *pelh₁u- (“many”).

text: more, -er (used to form comparatives of adjectives)
more, -er (used to form comparatives of adverbs)
(after a verb) more, -er (indicating a higher degree or quantity)
(preceded by a definite article) the most, -est (used to form superlatives of adjectives and adverbs)
(usually with the negative particle ne, see usage notes below) no longer, not ... any more
(elliptically, introducing each clause) the more ..., the more ...
(similarly, used with other comparatives) the more ..., the ...
examples: Ton voisin est plus moche que mon frère. ― Your neighbour is uglier than my brother.
Le tien est beaucoup plus grand que le mien. ― Yours is much bigger than mine.
Elle est plus belle que sa cousine. ― She is more beautiful than her cousin.
Elles sont toutes plus entêtées les unes que les autres. ― They are each more stubborn than the last.
Elle le fait plus rapidement que lui. ― She does it more quickly than he does.
plus vite ! ― faster!
Je travaille plus en ce moment. ― I am working more at the moment.
Je veux faire plus. ― I want to do more.
Elle a plus de chocolat. ― She has more chocolate.
Plus de la moitié reste. ― More than half is left.
Une heure de plus et il serait mort. ― One more hour and he would be dead.
Un kilo de plus, s'il vous plaît. ― One more kilo, please.
la plus grande ― the biggest
le plus difficile ― the most difficult
Tu n'existes plus. ― You no longer exist. / You don't exist any more.
Il n'y a plus de travail. ― There is no more work.
Plus je vois, plus je veux.}The more I see, the more I want.
The more I see, the more I want.
Plus j'écoute, moins je comprends.The more I listen, the less I understand.
The more I listen, the less I understand.

defs.etymology: See the etymology of the corresponding lemma form.

text: first/second-person singular past historic of plaire

defs.etymology: From Middle French mon, from Old French mun, mon, meon, from Vulgar Latin, Late Latin mum, a reduced variant of Latin meum, accusative masculine and neuter singular of meus. Probably influenced by Gaulish mon.

text: (possessive) my (used to qualify masculine nouns and vowel-initial words regardless of gender)
Followed by rank, obligatory way of addressing a (male) superior officer within the military. (Folk etymology: military-specific short for "monsieur".)
examples: J'ai perdu mon chapeau.I lost my hat.
I lost my hat.
La décision a été prise pendant mon absence.The decision was taken in my absence.
The decision was taken in my absence.

defs.etymology: From Middle French te, from Old French te, from Latin tē, (accusative of tū), from Proto-Indo-European *twé, *te, accusative of *túh₂ (“you”).

words: “te”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

examples: Il te cite souvent. ― He often quotes you.
Il te donne le livre. ― He gives you the book.
Tu te souviens d'elle. ― You remember her.

defs.etymology: From Middle French fait, from Old French fet, from Latin factum.

text: third-person singular present indicative of faire
fait (feminine faite, masculine plural faits, feminine plural faites)
examples: Je ne suis vraiment pas fait pour l'escalade.

defs.etymology:
From Middle French moy, from Old French mei, moi, mi (“me”), tonic form of me, from Latin mē (“me”), from Proto-Indo-European *(h₁)me-, *(h₁)me-n- (“me”). More at me.
See cognates in regional languages in France: Norman mei; Gallo mai; Picard moè; Bourguignon moi; Franco-Provençal mè; Occitan and Corsican me.

text: to me (first-person singular indirect object pronoun)
Elision of si (“if”) before il or ils.
examples: S’il vous plaît ― Please / Here you are.
S’il te plaît. ― Please / Here you are.
Je ne sais pas s’ils viendront demain.I don’t know if they will come tomorrow.
I don’t know if they will come tomorrow.

text: Elision of se before a word beginning with a vowel.
(informal) Elision of se before a word beginning with a consonant.
examples: Il s’habille. ― He’s dressing .
Il s’aime. ― He loves himself.
Ils s’aiment.They love themselves. / They love each other.
They love themselves. / They love each other.
Y s’bouge le cul ou quoi? ― Is he movin’ his ass or what?

defs.etymology: [1380], from Old French oïl (1100), compound of o (affirmative particle) and il (“he”). Cognate to Occitan òc (“yes”). See the Old French term for details.

examples: Antonym: non
Antonym: non

defs.etymology: Respectively from Latin vādit (indicative) and vāde (imperative), forms of vādō.

text: third-person singular imperfect indicative of être

defs.etymology: From Latin as.
From the verb avoir.

text: second-person singular present indicative of avoir
examples: Tu as un chien.You have a dog.
You have a dog.

defs.etymology: From Middle French faire, from Old French faire, feire, fere, from Vulgar Latin *fare, elided form of Latin facere, present active infinitive of faciō, from Proto-Italic *fakiō, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁- (“to put, place, set”). The past historic and imperfect subjunctive stem fi- (fis, fis, fit, ...) originate from Latin irregular perfect stem fēc- (fēcī), from faciō, with Romance metaphony rules.

text: (transitive) to say (of a person), to go (of an animal)
(transitive) to make (cause someone or something to do something)
(impersonal) to be (of the weather or various situations)
(reflexive, followed by an infinitive) to be, to get (used for a passive action)
(reflexive, ~ à) to become used to, to get used to
(slang, reflexive, transitive) to do (to have sex with)
examples: faire la vaisselle ― to do the washing-up.
Qu'est-ce que tu fais ? ― What are you doing?
Fais pas ça. ― Don't do that.
faire une erreur ― to make a mistake.
faire un voyage ― to take a trip
"Je t'aime," fit-il. ― "I love you," he said.
Le chat fait "miaou". ― The cat goes "meow".
Si on s'en allait tout là-haut pour mieux s'imprégner des couleurs, saurions-nous faire taire notre égo ?
Tu me fais rire. ― You make me laugh.
La chanson me fait pleurer. ― The song makes me cry.
Il fait chaud/froid/noir/beau dehors.It is hot/cold/dark/nice outside.
It is hot/cold/dark/nice outside.
Ça fait dix ans que nous nous connaissons.We have known each other for ten years.
We have known each other for ten years.
Elle se fait les ongles. ― She is doing her nails.
se faire piquer ― to be stung
Je me suis fait avoir. ― I got screwed.
Est-ce que tu t'es fait couper les cheveux ?Did you get your hair cut?
Did you get your hair cut?
Synonyms: s'adapter à, s'habituer à
Maintenant je pense que, si certains condamnés ont du courage, c'est parce qu'ils se sont faits à l'idée de mourir.
Je ne m'y suis toujours pas fait. ― I still haven't got used to it.

defs.etymology:
From Vulgar Latin illī, which sounded il in Old French, to which a plural -s was added. While il was the nominative form from late Latin, els, eus was the oblique form ("them") that had evolved from late Latin illōs, and is the ancestor of modern French eux'.
In Old French, "they", being a nominative, was il from late Latin *illi, thus it didn't have the final -s, thus it was il used both for "he" and "they". The -s was added at the end of the 13th century in some regions, at the time the declension system of Old French started to collapse. As a consequence, some oïl languages in France have retained the original Old French il-form, and in some other regions, the ils-form supplanted the older one. Some dialects have even retained both forms depending on the locals.
See cognates in regional languages in France: Angevin, Champenois, Lorrain, Orléanais, and Tourangeau is; Bourbonnais-Berrichon ils; Bourguignon âs; Franc-Comtois and Poitevin-Saintongeais és; Gallo i and iz; Norman i and is; Picard is and i; Franco-Provençal ils; Occitan els (Gascon eus); Catalan ells; Corsican egli.

words: “ils”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

defs.etymology: From Middle French sur, from Old French sur, seur, sor, soure, souvre, sovre (“on, upon, over”), from Latin super (“over, on, above”), from *eks-uper, from *h₁eǵʰs (“out of”) (Latin ex) and *upér (“above”), from *upo. Doublet of super, a borrowing. Cognate with Old English ofer (“over, above”). More at over.

examples: sept sur dix ― seven out of ten

defs.etymology: From Middle French sur, from Old French sur (“sour, bitter”), from Frankish *sūr (“acidic, sour”), from Proto-Germanic *sūraz (“sour”). More at English sour.

text: sur (feminine sure, masculine plural surs, feminine plural sures)

defs.etymology: From Latin quid; ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *kʷid, compare *kʷis. Cognate to English what, which differs due to changing under Grimm’s law.

text: (accusative, dative, genitive, oblique, not used in nominative, interrogative, relative) what (oblique pronoun)
examples: C'est quoi, ça ? ― What is this/that?
Il dit quoi ? ― What does he say?
De quoi il parle ? ― What is he talking about?
De quoi est-ce qu'il parle ? ― What is he talking about?
De quoi parle-t-il ? ― What is he talking about?
De quoi Marie parle-t-elle ? ― What is Marie talking about?
Y'a quoi à faire en Angleterre? Il n'y a pas de quoi.Is there aught to do in England? No, there is not.
Is there aught to do in England? No, there is not.
Alors, ce mec m'a dit de te donner son porte-monnaie, quoi.So, this guy, like, told me to give you his wallet.
So, this guy, like, told me to give you his wallet.

defs.etymology: From Middle French se, from Old French se, from Latin sē. See also soi.

text: The third-person reflexive and reciprocal direct and indirect object pronoun.
(Louisiana) The second-person plural reflexive and reciprocal direct and indirect object pronoun.

words: The other reflexive and reciprocal direct and indirect object pronouns: me, m', te, t', nous, vous.
The third-person reflexive and reciprocal disjunctive pronoun: soi.

examples: Je suis partie à la chasse et faut vous autres se comportes bien. ― I'm going hunting and y'all need to behave yourselves.

defs.etymology:
From Middle French comme, from Old French cum, com, conme, from Vulgar Latin *quomo, from Latin quōmodo. Later the conjunction et was added to com, resulting in comment.
Cognate to Italian come. See also Spanish como and Catalan com.

examples: La baladodiffusion est ainsi utilisée comme outil à potentiel cognitif, parce qu'elle  permet, relativement facilement, de diffuser un contenu audio ou vidéo qui peut,  par la suite, être écouté ou vu à tout moment par l'apprenant. Par ailleurs, les responsables du projet rappellent que les étudiants l'utilisent également pour écouter des balados de chroniques audio comme celles de The New England Journal of Medicine, une des plus importantes revues en médecine au monde.Therefore, podcasting is used as a tool for cognitive potential, because it allows for the relatively easy distribution of audio or video content, which, as a result, can be listened to or watched at any moment by the learner. Furthermore, the project managers remark that the students also use it to listen to audio podcast series, such as those of The New England Journal of Medicine, one of the most important medicine journals on Earth.

Therefore, podcasting is used as a tool for cognitive potential, because it allows for the relatively easy distribution of audio or video content, which, as a result, can be listened to or watched at any moment by the learner. Furthermore, the project managers remark that the students also use it to listen to audio podcast series, such as those of The New England Journal of Medicine, one of the most important medicine journals on Earth.
Je travaille comme artisteI work as an artist.
I work as an artist.
J'agis comme il faut.I act like I must.
I act like I must.
Comme tu es belle ce soir !How beautiful you are tonight!
How beautiful you are tonight!
Synonyms: puisque, car
J'entends les rires sur mon passage ; il paraît que je suis trop fragile. Mais comme les critiques glissent sur le plumage, être une plume rend les choses plus faciles.
Comme j'étais malade, il est venu me voir.As I was ill, he came to see me.
As I was ill, he came to see me.

text: first/second-person singular present indicative of savoir

defs.etymology: From Middle French estre, ultimately from a merger of Latin esse (“to be”) and stare (“to stand”). Some forms additionally derive from sedēre (“to sit”).

text: (auxiliary) Used to form the perfect and pluperfect tense of certain verbs (including all reflexive verbs)
(semi-auxiliary) to be (Used to form the passive voice)
examples: Vous devez être plus clairs.You must be clearer.
You must be clearer.
Après être allé au yoga, je suis rentré chez moi.After having gone to yoga, I came back home.
After having gone to yoga, I came back home.
Il peut être battu ce soir.He could be beaten this evening.
He could be beaten this evening.

text: (uncountable) being, the state or fact of existence

defs.etymology: From Old French ci (“here”), from Vulgar Latin *ecce hīc, with /i-/ added by analogy with Old French iluec (“there, in that place”), from Latin illoc.
From Old French ma, from Latin mea.

examples: Ma mère est venue me voir. My mother came to see me.
My mother came to see me.

defs.etymology: From Middle French toi, tei, from Old French tei, te, from Latin tē.

words: “toi”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

examples: Car tu es mon espérance, Seigneur Éternel! En toi je me confie dès ma jeunesse.For you are my hope, Eternal Lord! In you I entrust myself since my youth.
For you are my hope, Eternal Lord! In you I entrust myself since my youth.
J'ai besoin de toi. ― I need you
Et toi, ça va comment ?And you, how are you?
And you, how are you?
Souviens-toi de ce qui est vraiment important.Remember what is really important.
Remember what is really important.

Attends, tu m'as dit qu'il y a dans cette maison plus de deux-cents livres. Est-ce qu'ils sont tous à toi ?Wait, you told me that there are more than two hundred books in this house. Are they all yours?
Wait, you told me that there are more than two hundred books in this house. Are they all yours?
Toi, t'es quelque chose de différent.You are something different.
You are something different.

defs.etymology: From Old French dit, from Latin dictus.
From Latin dīcit, third-person singular present active indicative of dīcō.

examples: « Je m'appelle Paul, » dit-il. ― “My name is Paul,” he said.

defs.etymology: From Vulgar Latin *illūi, which is a Vulgar Latin form of Latin illī (dative singular of ille). The -ui ending in Vulgar Latin illui is due to the influence of cui.Cognate with Italian lui.

text: him, he; the third-person masculine singular personal pronoun used after a preposition, or as the predicate of a linking verb, or when disjoined from a sentence, or as a stressed subject
him, her; the third-person singular personal pronoun used as an indirect object
examples: J'habitais avec lui.I was living with him.
I was living with him.
C'est lui qui a dit cela.It's he who said that.
It's he who said that.
Lui, il n'en sait rien.He doesn't know anything about it.
He doesn't know anything about it.

Je crois aussi que je n'avais jamais si bien écouté, et que lui non plus n'avait jamais mis autant de patience à ses explications.I believe also that I had never listened so well, and that neither had he ever put so much patience into his explanations.
I believe also that I had never listened so well, and that neither had he ever put so much patience into his explanations.
Je lui ai donné le livre.I gave the book to him/her.
I gave the book to him/her.

defs.etymology: see the verb luire
From Middle French vostre, from Old French vostre, from Latin voster, vostrum, vostra(m), from earlier vester, from Proto-Italic *westeros.

words: “votre”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

text: second-person singular present indicative of être

defs.etymology: From Middle French parquoy, from Old French por quoi.

examples: Synonym: pourquoi que
Pourquoi as-tu fait cela ? ― Why did you do that?
Pourquoi n'a-t-il pas fini son travail ? ― Why hasn't he finished his work?
Je ne sais pas pourquoi il est parti. ― I don't know why he left.

defs.etymology: From Middle French où, from Old French ou, from Latin ubi (“where?”). The grave accent was added in Middle French to differentiate from ou (“or”).

examples: Synonym:  éyoù
Où est la gare?Where is the station?
Where is the station?
Comment savez-vous où j'habite ?How do you know where I live?
How do you know where I live?

Dans un monde où l'homme propose et la femme dispose, le célibataire a fait un choix conscient, dont il est pleinement responsable.In a world where the man proposes and the woman disposes, the single person has made a conscious choice for which he is fully responsible.
In a world where the man proposes and the woman disposes, the single person has made a conscious choice for which he is fully responsible.
Le jour où je suis devenu père.The day when I became a father.
The day when I became a father.
Un ciel plus pur et des dieux meilleurs, je t'offre à Rome où je me rends.A purer heaven and better gods I offer you in Rome, whither I go.
A purer heaven and better gods I offer you in Rome, whither I go.

defs.etymology: From Middle French la, from Old French la, from Latin illāc. The grave accent on the a was added to disambiguate with la (“the”).

examples: Antonym: ici
Je t'attendrai là. ― I'll wait for you there.
Synonym: ici
Je suis  là.I'm  here.
I'm  here.

defs.etymology: From Middle French rien, from Old French rien, from Latin rem, accusative of rēs (“thing”). Compare Catalan res (“nothing”) or Galician ren (“nothing”).

examples: Rien  ne se perd, rien  ne se crée, tout se transforme.Nothing  is lost, nothing is created, everything is transformed.
Nothing  is lost, nothing is created, everything is transformed.
Je n'ai besoin de rien d'autre.
En tous les bienfaits d'importance, la preuve ne peut avoir de lieu ; car il n'y a bien souvent que deux qui en sachent rien .

defs.etymology:
From Middle French ceste, from Old French ceste, from Vulgar Latin *eccista, feminine of *ecciste.
The loss of internal -s- triggered compensatory lengthening of the preceding vowel. Due to the unstressed position of this pronoun, however, the length was soon lost again, which explains the spelling without a circumflex (though the form cête was occasionally used). Compare notre and le nôtre.

text: third-person plural present indicative of être
examples: Où est-ce qu'ils sont? ― Where are they?

defs.etymology: From Middle French quand, quant, from Old French quant, qant, from Latin quandō.

examples: Appelez-moi quand vous arriverez chez vous ― Call me when you get home
Quand est-il mort ? ― When did he die?
Je ne sais pas quand est-ce qu'il est mort.I don't know when it was that he died.
I don't know when it was that he died.
Quand est-ce que vous voulez partir ?When do you want to leave?
When do you want to leave?

text: first/second-person singular present indicative of pouvoir

defs.etymology: From Middle French dire, from Old French dire, from Latin dīcō, from Proto-Italic *deikō, from Proto-Indo-European *déyḱti (“to show, point out”).

text: (informal) to be of interest to, to interest [+ à (someone)]
examples: Ça te dit de regarder un film de science-fiction? ― Do you want to watch a science fiction movie? What do you say to watching a science fiction movie?
Ça vous dit ? ― Are you interested [in doing this]? Are you up [for it]?
Il m'a demandé si ça nous dirait de nous joindre à eux plus tard. ― He asked me if we'd like to join them later.
Ça ne me dit trop rien d'y aller. ― I don't really want to go [there].
Ça me dit quelque chose. ― It rings a bell.
Ça ne me dit rien. ― It doesn't ring a bell.

defs.etymology: From Old French son, suen, suon, from Latin sonus (the current form may be remade after or influenced by sonner).

examples: Le son de ce piano est agréable.The sound of this piano is nice.
The sound of this piano is nice.

defs.etymology: From Middle French son, from Old French son, from Vulgar Latin sum, a reduced/atonic variant of suus, suum, from Proto-Italic *sowos, from Proto-Indo-European *sewos, from *swé (“self”).

text: (possessive) his, her, their, its (used to qualify masculine nouns and before a vowel)
examples: Elle a perdu son chapeau.She lost her hat.
She lost her hat.
Il a perdu son chapeau.He lost his hat.
He lost his hat.
J'aime son amie.I like their girlfriend.
I like their girlfriend.
La décision a été prise pendant son absence.The decision was taken in their absence.
The decision was taken in their absence.

defs.etymology: From Latin secundus (presumably through an earlier Old French form *seon; cf. an attested Medieval Latin seonno, seonnum). Cognate with Catalan segó, Old Occitan segon. The meaning derives from the fact that bran results from a second sifting of flour. Doublet of second, a borrowing.

examples: Ceci est du pain de son.This bread is done with bran.
This bread is done with bran.

text: second-person plural present indicative of avoir

defs.etymology: From Old French vois, ultimately from Latin vadō. The origin of -ais, while the final -s is not etymologically spurious in Old French, is unclear. Likely taken from Latin transeō < *trasjo to form the expected *vausjō (see more at Reichenau Glossary). The element *vau- comes from *vaō (infinitive *vare), elided form of vadō.

text: first-person singular present indicative of aller
first-person singular present indicative of vader

defs.etymology: From Old French a +‎ lors. Compare Italian allora, Spanish alora, Occitan alara and Catalan aleshores.

text: (acknowledgement of previous statement) so, well, well then
examples: Alors on reste ici ce soir. ― Well then, let's stay here tonight.

defs.etymology: From Old French ton, tos, from Latin tuus.

examples: Tu as pensé à prendre ton livre ?Did you remember to bring your book?
Did you remember to bring your book?
Ton écriture est jolie.Your writing is pretty.
Your writing is pretty.
J'aime beaucoup ton manteau.I really like your coat.
I really like your coat.

defs.etymology: Borrowed from Latin tonus. Doublet of tonus, a later borrowing.

examples: Il y a un ton entre do et réDoh and ray are separated by one tone.
Doh and ray are separated by one tone.
Je n'aime pas le ton sur lequel tu me parles!I don’t like your tone!
I don’t like your tone!
Différents tons de rouge.Several shades of red.
Several shades of red.

defs.etymology: comme +‎ -ment

examples: Comment te sens-tu ? ― How do you feel?

defs.etymology: From Middle French par, from Old French par, from Latin per, from Proto-Indo-European *peri.

text: by (used to introduce a means; used to introduce an agent in a passive construction))
from (used to describe the origin of something, especially a view or movement)
on (situated on, used in certain phrases)
on, at, in (used to denote a time when something occurs)
out of (used to describe the reason for something)
examples: par la fenêtre ― through the window
aller par le parc ― go through the park
voyager par train ― travel by train
par surprise ― by surprise
le bateau est attaqué par des pirates. ― the boat is [being] attacked by pirates.
Viens par ici ! ― Come over here!
voir par devant ― see from the back
le liquide est arrivé par le robinet ― the liquid arrived from the tap
par tout le cinéma ― all around the cinema
par terre ― on the ground
par un beau jour ― on a nice day
par un soir ― in one evening
marcher par deux ― walk in twos
trois fois par semaine ― three times a week
par pure colère ― out of pure anger
par tristesse ― out of sadness

defs.etymology: From Old French ou, from Latin aut.

examples: La baladodiffusion est ainsi utilisée comme outil à potentiel cognitif, parce qu'elle  permet, relativement facilement, de diffuser un contenu audio ou vidéo qui peut,  par la suite, être écouté ou vu à tout moment par l'apprenant.Therefore, podcasting is used as a tool for cognitive potential, because it allows for the relatively easy distribution of audio or video content, which, as a result, can be listened to or watched at any moment by the learner.

Therefore, podcasting is used as a tool for cognitive potential, because it allows for the relatively easy distribution of audio or video content, which, as a result, can be listened to or watched at any moment by the learner.
Ou il est fou ou il est bête.Either he's mad or he's stupid.
Either he's mad or he's stupid.

defs.etymology: From Old French chose, from Latin causa. Compare Italian cosa, Portuguese coisa, Spanish cosa among many others. Compare cause, a borrowed doublet.

examples: Synonym: truc

Les Agrigentins avaient en usage commun d’enterrer sérieusement les bêtes qu’ils avaient eu chères, comme les chevaux de quelque rare mérite, les chiens et les oiseaux utiles, ou même qui avaient servi de passe-temps à leurs enfants : et la magnificence qui leur était ordinaire en toutes autres choses paraissait aussi singulièrement à la somptuosité et nombre de monuments élevés à cette fin, qui ont duré en parade plusieurs siècles depuis.The Agrigentines had a common use solemnly to inter the beasts they had a kindness for, as horses of some rare quality, dogs, and useful birds, and even those that had only been kept to divert their children; and the magnificence that was ordinary with them in all other things, also particularly appeared in the sumptuosity and numbers of monuments erected to this end, and which remained in their beauty several ages after.

The Agrigentines had a common use solemnly to inter the beasts they had a kindness for, as horses of some rare quality, dogs, and useful birds, and even those that had only been kept to divert their children; and the magnificence that was ordinary with them in all other things, also particularly appeared in the sumptuosity and numbers of monuments erected to this end, and which remained in their beauty several ages after.

defs.etymology: From Middle French bon, from Old French bon, from Latin bonus (“good”), from Old Latin duenos, later duonus, from Proto-Italic *dwenos, from Proto-Indo-European *dew- (“to show favor, revere”).

text: bon (feminine bonne, masculine plural bons, feminine plural bonnes, comparative meilleur, superlative le meilleur)
(slang, slightly derogatory, of a woman) sexy, hot, smoking hot
examples: le bon usage ― the correct usage
être dans la bonne direction ― to be going the right way, to be heading the right way
Choisissez la bonne réponse.Choose the correct response.
Choose the correct response.
Cette meuf est fin bonne !That chick is fine as hell!
That chick is fine as hell!
Synonyms: coupon, billet

text: third-person plural present indicative of avoir

defs.etymology: From Middle French merci, mercy, from Old French merci, from Latin mercēdem, accusative singular of mercēs (“wages, fee, price”).

examples: merci pour ton aidethank you for your help
thank you for your help

defs.etymology: From Old French juste, in this form probably borrowed from Latin iūstus, jūstus, from Proto-Italic *jowestos, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂yew-. The Old French form just may have been inherited, however, and perhaps later modified based on the Latin.

examples: Elle n'est que trop juste en un si grand malheurIt is only too appropriate in such misfortune
It is only too appropriate in such misfortune
Il est juste là!It is right there!
It is right there!
Synonyms: ne que, seulement, rien de plus
Je veux juste un œuf.I just want one egg.
I just want one egg.
J'en prends juste un tout petit peu.

defs.etymology: From Middle French trés, from Old French trés, inherited from Latin trāns, from Proto-Indo-European *terh₂- (“through, throughout, over”). Doublet of trans- or trans.
From Old French ja més, jamés (“ever”), from Latin iam magis (“once more”). Compare Spanish jamás, Italian giammai, Occitan jamai and Portuguese jamais.

examples: Je ne l’ai jamais vue. ― I’ve never seen her.
Es-tu jamais allé en France ? ― Have you ever been to France?

defs.etymology: From Old French esté, from Latin aestās, aestātem, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *h₂eydʰ- (“burn; fire”).

From Old French esté, past participle of ester (“to stand, to be (stative)”) (which was conflated with estre in Old French); from Latin stātus, past participle of stāre (“to stand”). Compare also the noun état.
From Old French ausi, from Latin aliud sic (“another thing thus”).

examples: Moi aussi ― Me too.
Dans le bois, quand mon fils dormait et que tu dormais aussi, j'ai failli t'embrasser tout doucement.In the wood, when my son was sleeping and you were sleeping too, I almost kissed you softly.
In the wood, when my son was sleeping and you were sleeping too, I almost kissed you softly.
Mon fils est rendu aussi grand que moi.My son has gotten as tall as me.
My son has gotten as tall as me.
